title: McCaul Slams White House Comments on Afghanistan Withdrawal: "Disgraceful and Insulting" - Committee on Foreign Affairs

last_post.content: “John Kirby’s comments during today’s White House press briefing were disgraceful and insulting," says House foreign affairs committee chair Michael McCaul (R-TX). "President Biden made the decision to withdraw and even picked the exact date; he is responsible for the massive failures in planning and execution." https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/press-release/mccaul-slams-white-house-comments-on-afghanistan-withdrawal-disgraceful-and-insulting/

Here you can listen to some cool Ethiopian scales called 'kignits':

https://www.temesgen.com/learn/music-theory#h.p_nGjeUVVvlg6C

Twenty of them, all pentatonic! One of the most popular is Ambassel 1. If you listen to just one, please try that one.

Ambassel 1 sounds good because of its charming mix of symmetry and asymmetry. If you count the octave, this scale consists of two identical blocks. But each of these blocks is very lopsided: first a half step and then four half steps!

Some kignits are just modes of the familiar major pentatonic scale - the one you can get by playing just the black keys on the piano. This is a fave in jazz and rock. But other kignits are new tools you can add to your toolkit!

title: Validated Names for Experimental Studies on Race and Ethnicity

last_post.content:
In many studies, we use names (like vignettes, or applications).
Names bring a lot of baggage with them.

For example, with ‘Hazel’, you already are forming ideas about age, sex, likely SES etc.

Same with Arthur Worthington III,
or Ozamataz Buckshank.

No name is neutral.

In this study, 4,026 people rated 600 names on numerous attributes.

Full data is available here https://osf.io/ahpvq/

Now you can ‘match’ names on all sorts of characteristics

From @cdcrabtree

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-023-01947-0

title: The Three-Legged Stool: A Manifesto for a Smaller, Denser Internet - Initiative for Digital Public Infrastructure

last_post.content:
Social media is under attack, from state legislators, from the US Congress, from reckless billionaires. At @iDPI_umass
we believe something vastly better is possible - conversations we host, moderate, control and learn from. Read our new manifesto here: https://publicinfrastructure.org/2023/03/29/the-three-legged-stool/

We're proposing a vision of social media that's plural, public-spirited and participatory. It embraces existing platforms as well as creates infrastructure for new, smaller, civic-focused conversations. It relies on tools for accessing social media that give us more control over the voices and topics we here, and gives us the ability to audit and interrogate the algorithms we choose to use to filter and sort what we see.

It's not just a manifesto, but a roadmap. Our civic social platform Smalltown is live in Amherst, and the alpha of our aggregator Gobo should be released later this month. Give our paper a read and let us know if and how you want to be part of this ecosystem.

title: Sparks of Artificial General Intelligence: Early experiments with GPT-4

last_post.content:
When intelligent people well versed in the technology and its fundamentals arrive at the conclusion that GPT-4 represents a spark of intelligence, rather than an extremely elaborate but still rote memorization machine, I can't help but feel that we might be witnessing the end of human history: we're going to drown in not disinfo after all, but instead in our own inability to recognize human experience from anthropomorphized simulations.

title: Something in the water: the mythology of Snow’s map of cholera

last_post.content:
@kennethfield, cartographer and author, wrote this fascinating debunking of the cholera map story in 2020.

- Map came after the outbreak ended
- It wasn’t the first such map
- It wasn’t designed by Snow

https://www.esri.com/arcgis-blog/products/arcgis-pro/mapping/something-in-the-water-the-mythology-of-snows-map-of-cholera/

Springer Makes Open Source Chapter Of Upcoming Handbook Of Geographic Information Freely Accessible In April
-
https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-53125-6_30 <-- shared & free journal issue
-
[a good overview of open source GIS software stacks - with an OUTSTANDING and comprehensive reference list/links at the end!]
“... As a service to the readers, the reference section of this chapter includes scientific video recordings which provide additional content regarding software capabilities, historical notes and background information: #Actinia, #GeoBlackLight, #GeoPaparazzi, #GeoPython, #GeoServer, #GeoTools, #GMT, #GRASSGIS, #gvSIG, #JTS, #Leaflet, #MapServer, #NASAWorldWind, #OSGeoLive. #PostGIS, #PROJ, #QGIS, #rasdaman. In addition, scientific videos about the #OSGeo Foundation and the annual #SolKatzAwards or #GeospatialFreeandOpenSourceSoftware are included…”

title: The Spatial Humanities: a challenge to the all-knowing map

last_post.content:
RT @StuartEDunn@twitter.activitypub.actor

My Inaugural Lecture (also marking the end of my time as Head of Department of @kingsdh@twitter.activitypub.actor) "The Spatial Humanities: A Challenge to the All-Knowing Map" will be held at King's on 20th June. Drinks aftwards. It will also be livestreamed (not the drinks alas).

title: Local NewsMatch funders outpaced national donors for the first time in 2022

last_post.content:
In 2020, NewsMatch recorded more than 1 million donations from nearly 434,000 unique donors. Two years later, those numbers have dropped to 344,000 donations from 231,000 donors.

How concerned should nonprofit newsrooms be about some of these downward trends? https://www.niemanlab.org/2023/04/local-newsmatch-funders-outpaced-national-donors-for-the-first-time-in-2022/

Opinion out in WPL v. SAS. Fed. Cir. affirms summary judgment for WPL—SAS failed to show infringement of any protectable elements.

I've only skimmed it, but it's nice to see a court taking a plaintiff to task (at least a little) for their consistent refusal to identify what protectable elements they were actually alleging were infringed. All too common a tactic.

Opinion: https://cafc.uscourts.gov/opinions-orders/21-1542.OPINION.4-6-2023_2106573.pdf

So many highlights in this paper "Eight Things to Know about Large Language Models" by Sam Bowman

If you've not been staying entirely on top of modern LLM research this might be a great place to start catching up - it's succinct, readable and full of fascinating details

PDF: https://cims.nyu.edu/~sbowman/eightthings.pdf

title: Clarence Thomas Secretly Accepted Luxury Trips From Major GOP Donor

last_post.content:
Here's the clip mentioned in the
@ProPublica story, of the #ClarenceThomas documentary -- funded by his billionaire pal Harlan Crow -- where the #SCOTUS justice speaks lovingly of "seeing the regular parts" of the US --

"I prefer the RV parks. I prefer the Wal-Mart parking lots to the beaches and things like that."

Thomas glosses over the fact that he and Crow have regularly traveled the world aboard the #Texas billionaire's private jet and luxury superyacht.

title: Tasked With Stopping Terror, Colorado’s Intel Agency Monitors Students Protesting Gun Violence

last_post.content: The Colorado Information Analysis Center (a police intelligence agency) is tasked with gathering intelligence to prevent terrorist attacks. Instead, it used its resources to monitor students planning peaceful protests against gun violence https://theintercept.com/2023/04/05/colorado-student-gun-violence-protest/

title: Slint 1.0: The Next-Generation Native GUI Toolkit Matures

last_post.content:
Just discovered Slint (@slint), A Native GUI Toolkit that works on Desktop (Linux/Win/Mac/WebAssembly) and Embedded (Cortex-M/-A/x86/RISC-V/Xtensa).
One of the co-founders has been the lead developer for QML.
It's written in Rust but also works with C++ and NodeJS.
Very promising!

https://slint-ui.com/blog/announcing-slint-1.0.html

title: Algorithmic Aftermath: Researcher Explores the Damage They Can Leave Behind | College of Computing

last_post.content:
🎉 Excited to share this in-depth press coverage of our research on the Algorithmic Imprint! The article has exclusive behind-the-scenes details.

🤗 On a personal note, this work is close to my heart. I was finally able to bridge my two worlds: my community in Bangladesh and my research on #ResponsibleAI.

✨ Collab w/ Ranjit Singh, Jacob Metcalf from @datasociety and @Riedl.

🎯 Can you think of examples of algorithmic imprints?

https://www.cc.gatech.edu/news/algorithmic-aftermath-researcher-explores-damage-they-can-leave-behind
